But his story gets into the Record, via Senator Bennett C. Clark, who relays to Maj. Gen. H. H. Arnold the news of the bomb, as he had it from Mr. Barlow, and asks the general what about it. The general tells of army reports that the German bombs in Barcelona “killed every human being within the range of a quarter of a mile." The USA was supposed to have used about worth of Bartow bombs and weapons in the World war. Several weeks ago, the senate voted himl in royalties for the wartime ase of his patents. He it a prolific inventor, now consulting engineer for the Glenn I. Martin Co., of Balti more, builders at bombing planes. He describes the new German bomb as truly horrendous, basically a combination of liquid oxygen and carbon, but with ether ingredients, such as magnesium and aluminum. He thinks he can Just about match it with his L. O. X. bomb. In 632, he offered to President Hoover a simple buttonpushing rig which would wipe out a city hundreds of miles away. Even with the backing of Senator Frazier of North Dakota, he failed to got the government interested and was said to have offered his device to Russia and Germany. Later, he had other disappointing encounters in congress, offering, among other things, a shockproof battleship, on whose ribs the heaviest projectile would be just the pat of a powderpuff.

WHHEN Britain and the United ” States begin to exchange cook ing recipes, they are really getting neighborly. Carlota, the British poetess, who arived here recentiy, not friendly relations, prefaced her trip with a radio appeal for American recipes. She got more than 2,000. When we get to toiling each other about our operations, the entente will be com plete. Carlota is the wife of Louis Oppeoheimer, managing direc tor of the South African dia mond syndicate. She has pub lished many books of poetry In many countries, speaks seven languages fluently, and finds time to convert old houses Into charming dwellings or "mews," for working people. Her London home is one of the great social and political salons of England. She knows the proverbial way to the now somewhat intransi gent American heart. Her visit marks a pleasant departure from the customary exchange of recipes for cooking TNT and the like
